"'''Television and the Public Interest'''" was a speech given by [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) chairman [[Newton N. Minow]] to the convention of the [[National Association of Broadcasters]] on May 9, 1961. The speech was Minow's first major speech after he was appointed chairman of the FCC by President [[John F. Kennedy]]. In the speech, Minow referred to American commercial television programming as a "'''vast wasteland'''" and advocated for programming in the [[public interest]]. In hindsight, the speech marked the end of a [[Golden Age of Television]] that had run through the 1950s, contrasting the highbrow programs of that decade with what had appeared on American television in [[1960–61 United States network television schedule|1960 and 1961]]. {{quote|When television is good, nothing — not the theater, not the magazines or newspapers — nothing is better. But when television is bad, nothing is worse. I invite each of you to sit down in front of your own television set when your station goes on the air and stay there, for a day, without a book, without a magazine, without a newspaper, without a profit and loss sheet or a rating book to distract you. Keep your eyes glued to that set until the station signs off. I can assure you that what you will observe is a vast wasteland. You will see a procession of game shows, formula comedies about totally unbelievable families, blood and thunder, mayhem, violence, sadism, murder, western bad men, western good men, private eyes, gangsters, more violence, and cartoons. And endlessly commercials — many screaming, cajoling, and offending. And most of all, boredom. True, you'll see a few things you will enjoy. But they will be very, very few. And if you think I exaggerate, I only ask you to try it.Newton N. Minow, "[http://www.americanrhetoric.com/speeches/newtonminow.htm Television and the Public Interest]", address to the National Association of Broadcasters, Washington, D.C., May 9, 1961.}} In his speech Minow also shared advice to his audience:
Television and all who participate in it are jointly accountable to the American public for respect for the special needs of children, for community responsibility, for the advancement of education and culture, for the acceptability of the program materials chosen, for decency and decorum in production, and for propriety in advertising. This responsibility cannot be discharged by any given group of programs, but can be discharged only through the highest standards of respect for the American home, applied to every moment of every program presented by television. Program materials should enlarge the horizons of the viewer, provide him with wholesome entertainment, afford helpful stimulation, and remind him of the responsibilities which the citizen has toward his society.{{cite web|url=http://www.terramedia.co.uk/reference/documents/vast_wasteland.htm|title=Newton Minow: The 'vast wasteland' of television speech|publisher=|accessdate=10 June 2016}}
It was a landmark speech for the medium of [[television]], at a time when there were only three networks in the United States and when the realm of television was much less vast than it would later become. Nonetheless, it is counted as one of a hundred best American speeches of the 20th century by several authorities and selected as one of twenty-five 'Speeches that Changed the World' by Vital Speeches.[http://www.mcmurry.com/pdf/01_04_07_BestofVitalSpeeches.pdf The Best of Vital Speeches of the Day: 25 Speeches That Changed Our World.] ''McMurry.'' 4 Jan. 2007.{{Dead link|date=November 2018}} Related writings include his book (co-written with Craig LaMay) ''Abandoned in the Wasteland: Children, Television, & the First Amendment''. The phrase "vast wasteland" was suggested to Minow by his friend, reporter and freelance writer [[John Bartlow Martin]]. Martin had recently watched twenty consecutive hours of television as research for a magazine piece, and concluded it was "a vast wasteland of junk." During the editing process, Minow cut the words "of junk." {{cite news|last=Fallows|first=James|title=Where the Phrase 'Vast Wasteland' Came From|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2011/05/where-the-phrase-vast-wasteland-came-from/238743/|accessdate=12 May 2011|newspaper=The Atlantic Monthly|date=11 May 2011}} Minow often remarks that the two words best remembered from the speech are "vast wasteland," but the two words he wishes would be remembered are "public interest."{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Ted|title="A Vast Wasteland," 50 Years Later|url=http://www.wilshireandwashington.com/2011/05/a-vast-wasteland-50-years-later.html|accessdate=12 May 2011|newspaper=Variety magazine|date=9 May 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517224745/http://www.wilshireandwashington.com/2011/05/a-vast-wasteland-50-years-later.html|archivedate=17 May 2011|df=}} The lambasting of the state of United States television programming prompted Sherwood Schwartz to name the boat on his television show ''[[Gilligan's Island]]'' after Newton Minow; the wreck was named the ''Minnow''.{{cite book|author=Schwartz, Sherwood|title=Inside Gilligan's Island |year=1994|pages=xv}} cited in {{cite journal|url=http://digitalcommons.law.scu.edu/lawreview/vol39/iss1/4/|title=Legal Tales from Gilligan's Island|author=Jarvis, Robert M. |journal=Santa Clara Law Review|publisher=Santa Clara University Law School |year=1998|volume=39|pages=185|accessdate=2014-04-01}} ==References== == External links == {{wikiquote|Newton N. Minow}} *[http://www.americanrhetoric.com/speeches/newtonminow.htm Complete text and audio of Minow's speech] from AmericanRhetoric.com * [https://web.archive.org/web/20021217012228/http://www.media-awareness.ca/eng/issues/violence/resource/articles/toxict.htm ''Maclean's'' article, June 17, 1996] * [http://janda.org/b20/News%20articles/vastwastland.htm "Update" April 24, 2001] * [http://www.museum.tv/archives/etv/M/htmlM/minownewton/minownewton.htm "Museum of Broadcast Communications article on Minow and the speech"] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070415220919/http://www.law.indiana.edu/fclj/pubs/v55no3.html "Assessment of the speech by Minow and 24 commentators for the Federal Communications Law Journal" May 2003] * [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5775619 "Interview with Minow about the state of television in 2006] * [http://www.learnoutloud.com/Catalog/History/Speeches/Great-Speeches-in-History-Podcast/21306 MP3 recording of the entire Minow speech, "Television and the Public Interest"] {{Gilligan's Island}} [[Category:Federal Communications Commission]] [[Category:Television in the United States]] [[Category:1961 in American politics]] [[Category:1961 in American television]] [[Category:Television criticism]] [[Category:1961 in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:1961 speeches]] [[Category:May 1961 events]] [[Category:Gilligan's Island]]

{{EngvarB|date=June 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{refimprove|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox Magazine |title = The Strand Magazine |image_file = The Strand Magazine, bound volume 1894.JPG |image_size = |image_caption = Bound volume of ''The Strand Magazine'' for January–June 1894 featuring George Charles Haité's cover design |editor = |frequency = Monthly |circulation = |category = |company = [[George Newnes]] Ltd |publisher = |firstdate = January 1891 |country = UK |language = English |issn = |finaldate = March 1950 |finalnumber = 711 }}
'''''The Strand Magazine''''' was a monthly [[magazine]] founded by [[George Newnes]], composed of short fiction and general interest articles. It was published in the United Kingdom from January 1891<ref>{{cite web|author1=Howard Cox|author2=Simon Mowatt|title=Technology, Organisation and Innovation: The Historical Development of the UK Magazine Industry|url=http://aut.researchgateway.ac.nz/bitstream/handle/10292/1129/Technology_organisation.pdf?sequence=1&origin=publication_detail|work=Auckland University of Technology|accessdate=25 June 2016|format=Research paper|date=2003}}</ref> to March 1950, running to 711 issues,<ref>Ashley, Mike. ''The Age of the Storytellers'', The British Library and Oak Knoll Press, p. 196. 2006. {{ISBN|0-7123-0698-6}}</ref> though the first issue was on sale well before Christmas 1890. Its immediate popularity is evidenced by an initial sale of nearly 300,000. Sales increased in the early months, before settling down to a circulation of almost 500,000 copies a month which lasted well into the 1930s. It was edited by [[Herbert Greenhough Smith]] from 1891 to 1930. The magazine's original offices were in Burleigh Street off [[Strand, London|The Strand]], London. It was revived in 1998 as a quarterly magazine.
It was normally bound as six-monthly volumes, from January to June and July to December, but from the mid-1930s this varied, and the final volumes in the late 1940s ran from October to March and April to September, the final volume CXVIII (118) running from October 1949 to March 1950.
==Fiction== The [[Sherlock Holmes]] short stories by [[Arthur Conan Doyle]] were first published in ''The Strand'' with illustrations by [[Sidney Paget]]. With the serialisation of Doyle's ''[[The Hound of the Baskervilles]]'', sales reached their peak. Readers lined up outside the magazine's offices, waiting to get the next instalment. [[E. W. Hornung]]'s stories about [[A. J. Raffles]], the "gentleman thief", first appeared in ''The Strand'' in the 1890s. Other contributors included [[Grant Allen]], [[Margery Allingham]], [[J. E. Preston Muddock]], [[H. G. Wells]], [[Edmund Clerihew Bentley|E. C. Bentley]], [[Agatha Christie]], [[Mary Angela Dickens]], [[C. B. Fry]], [[Walter Goodman]], [[E. Nesbit]], [[W. W. Jacobs]], [[Rudyard Kipling]], [[Arthur Morrison]], [[Dorothy L. Sayers]], [[Georges Simenon]], [[Edgar Wallace]], [[Max Beerbohm]], [[P. G. Wodehouse]], [[Dornford Yates]] and [[Winston Churchill]]. Once a sketch drawn by [[Queen Victoria]] of one of her children appeared with her permission.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/StrandMagazine3/Strand3#page/n1/mode/2up |title=''The Strand Magazine'', Volume 1, Issue 3 (March 1891), pp. 226ff |publisher=Archive.org |date= |accessdate=2014-03-03}}</ref>
==Puzzles== In addition to the many fiction pieces and illustrations, ''The Strand'' was also known for some time as the source of ground-breaking brain teasers, under a column called "Perplexities", first written by [[Henry Dudeney]]. Dudeney introduced many new concepts to the puzzle world, including the first known [[cross-figure|crossnumber]] puzzle, in 1926. In that same year, Dudeney produced an article, "The Psychology of Puzzle Crazes", reflecting and analysing the demand for such works. He edited Perplexities from 1910 until he died in 1930. G.H. Savage became the column's editor, soon to be joined by [[W. T. Williams|William Thomas Williams]] (as W.T. Williams), who in 1935 authored the best-known [[cross-figure]] puzzle of today. The puzzle goes by many names, the original being "The Little Pigley Farm". It has also been known as "Dog's Mead", "Little Pigley", "Little Piggly Farm", "Little Pigsby", "Pilgrims’ Plot", and "Dog Days".
==Cover== The magazine's iconic cover, an illustration looking eastwards down London's [[Strand, London|Strand]] towards [[St Mary-le-Strand]], with the title suspended on telegraph wires, was the work of Victorian artist and designer [[George Charles Haité]]. The initial cover featured a corner plaque showing the name of Burleigh Street, home to the magazine's original offices. The lettering on the plaque in Haité's design was later changed when Newnes moved to the adjacent address of Southampton Street. A variation of the same design was featured on the cover of a sister title, ''The Strand Musical Magazine''.
==Final days== The magazine format changed to the smaller [[digest size]] in October 1941.<ref>Ashley, p. 205.</ref> ''The Strand Magazine'' ceased publication in March 1950, forced out of the market by declining circulation and rising costs. Its last editor was [[Macdonald Hastings]], distinguished [[war correspondent]] and later TV reporter and contributor to the ''[[Eagle (comic)|Eagle]]'' boys' comic.
==United States edition==
The magazine also published a United States edition from February 1891 through February 1916. In its early years, the contents of the U.S. edition were identical with those of the U.K. edition, though usually with a one-month time lag. As the years went on there were some differences in the contents of the two editions, reflecting fiction for which ''The Strand'' did not hold the U.S. rights (such as ''The Return of Sherlock Holmes'', which was commissioned by ''Collier's'') and non-fiction that would not interest most U.S. readers (such as articles about personalities in the House of Commons). The circulation of the U.S. edition was minimal in the early 1890s but was reported at 150,000 by 1898. The U.S. edition was discontinued in 1916 due to logistical difficulties arising from World War I.<ref>See Philip G. Bergem, A Sherlockian and Doylean Checklist of ''The Strand Magazine'', pp. 1, 5, 8-10; Frederick Faxon, "Magazine Perplexities I. ''Strand Magazine,'' 1 Bulletin of Bibliography 8, at 122 (Jan. 1899); Bliss Austin, "Wanderings on a Foreign Strand", Baker Street Miscellanea, No. 17, p. 1 (Mar. 1979); "American Strand Magazine Quits," ''The Fourth Estate'' 17 (Jan. 22, 1916).</ref>
==1998 revival== {{Infobox Magazine |title = The Strand Magazine |image_file = |image_size = |image_caption = |editor = |frequency = Quarterly |circulation = |category = |company = |publisher = |firstdate = December 1998 |country = United States |based = [[Birmingham, Michigan]] |language = English |issn = |finaldate = |finalnumber = | website={{URL|strandmag.com}} }}
''The Strand'' was brought back into publication in 1998 as a quarterly magazine, now based in [[Birmingham, Michigan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/books/ct-books-strand-cornell-woolrich-story-strand,0,7512816.story|author=Julia Keller|title=Tough guys, unite|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> It has published fiction by many well-known writers including [[John Mortimer]], [[Ray Bradbury]], [[Alexander McCall Smith]], [[Ruth Rendell]], [[Colin Dexter]], [[Edward Hoch]], [[James Grippando]], and [[Tennessee Williams]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.strandmag.com/htm/strandmag_history.htm |title=history of the Strand Magazine |first=Chris |last=Willis |publisher=Strandmag.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/11/10/agatha-christie-story-idUSN1051430320091110 |title=Lost Agatha Christie story to be published in U.S. |publisher=Reuters |date=10 November 2009|accessdate=2014-03-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/03/25/unpublished-tennessee-williams-story-to-appear/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=0|title=Unpublished Tennessee Williams Story to Appear|accessdate=2012-03-26}}</ref>

{{italic title}} {{Infobox Painting | image_file=File:The Wounded Deer 1946.jpg | title=The Wounded Deer | other_language_1=Spanish | other_title_1=El venado herido | artist=[[Frida Kahlo]] | year=1946 | type=[[Oil painting|Oil]] on [[masonite]] | height_metric=22.4 | width_metric=30 | city=Houston, Texas | owner=[[Carolyn Farb]] }} '''''The Wounded Deer''''' (''El venado herido'' in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]) is an [[oil painting]] by [[Mexican art]]ist [[Frida Kahlo]] created in 1946. It is also known as '''''The Little Deer'''''. Through ''The Wounded Deer'', Frida Kahlo shares her enduring physical and emotional suffering with her audience, as she did throughout her creative oeuvre. This painting in particular was created towards the end of Kahlo's life, when her health was in decline. Kahlo combines [[pre-Columbian]], [[Buddhist]], and [[Christian]] symbols to express her wide spectrum of influences and beliefs.
==Background== Frida Kahlo was plagued with poor health her entire life. In 1925, she was in a bus accident that resulted in serious injuries to her entire body. Her spine, ribs, pelvis, right leg, and abdomen were particularly damaged.<ref>Drucker, Malka.''Frida Kahlo: Torment and Triumph in her Life and Art''. New York: Bantam Books, 1991. Pages 23-26.</ref> She would deal with the wounds from this accident for the rest of her life. Kahlo painted this [[self-portrait]] before an operation on her spine, which would leave her bedridden for almost a year. During her recovery, she wore a steel corset, which can be seen in her late self-portraits.<ref>Herrera, Hayden. ''Frida Kahlo: the Paintings''. New York: Harper Perennial, 1993. Page 191.</ref> Her right leg would eventually be amputated up to her knee, as a result of [[gangrene]].<ref>Herrera, Hayden. ''Frida Kahlo: the Paintings''. New York: Harper Perennial, 1993. Page 191.</ref>
The variety of cultural influences reflect Kahlo's own background. She had a German father and a Mexican mother, thus she was aware of traditional European and Mexican ideas during her childhood.<ref>Drucker, Malka. ''Frida Kahlo: Torment and Triumph in her Life and Art''. New York: Bantam Books, 1991. Pages 1-10.</ref> It is also known that Kahlo was interested in Eastern Religion during the later years of her life.<ref>Kahlo, Frida. ''Frida Kahlo''. London: Tate Publishing, 2005. Pages 42-43.</ref>
In 1940, Kahlo married fellow [[Mexican art]]ist [[Diego Rivera]] for the second time. Their second marriage saw many of the same problems as their first, filled with jealousy, affairs, and arguments.<ref>Drucker, Malka. ''Frida Kahlo: Torment and Triumph in her Life and Art''. New York: Bantam Books, 1991. Page 105.</ref>
Around the time she created ''The Wounded Deer'', Frida Kahlo made a drawing of a young deer in her diary, which is thought to be inspired by her pet deer, Granizo.<ref>Kahlo, Frida. ''The Diary of Frida Kahlo: an Intimate Self-Portrait''. New York: N.H. Abrams, 1995. Page 265.</ref>
''The Wounded Deer'' was given by Frida Kahlo to close friends Arcady and Lina Boytler as a wedding gift.<ref>Herrera, Hayden. ''Frida Kahlo: the Paintings''. New York: Harper Perennial. Page 188.</ref>
==Description== In ''The Wounded Deer'', Frida Kahlo paints herself as an animal and human hybrid. She has the body of a deer along with antlers extending from her own head. The deer is standing up, its legs extended in action. Its front right leg is elevated off the ground, as though it is injured or in motion. In the deer's body are nine arrows, creating wounds from which blood flows. The deer is in a forest; nine trees are on the right of the deer, and a broken branch lies in the foreground. Only the tree trunks can be seen in the [[picture plane]]; none of the foliage above is visible. One of the branches on the tree in the right of the foreground is severed. It is probable that the detached limb is the branch located on the ground before the deer. The broken branch is prominent, as it is given more detail by the artist than all of the forest floor. Kahlo's face stares stoically at the viewer, showing little sign of pain. Her neck and head are upright and alert. A set of deer ears emerge from behind Kahlo's own. In the background a body of water is present, which can be seen through the trees. Though the sky is bright, a bolt of lightning strikes down from a white cloud. The word "carma" ([[karma]]) is written in the bottom left corner of the painting, after the artist's signature and the year of creation. ''The Wounded Deer'' is mostly rendered with green, brown, and gray tones, as well as small measures of blue and red. The painting’s physical dimensions are very modest, measuring at only 22.4 x 30 centimeters.<ref>Souter, Gerry. ''Frida Kahlo: Beneath the Mirror''. Parkstone International, 2010. Page 122.</ref>
==Interpretation and analysis== In this painting, Kahlo shares her lifelong splanchnic pain with her audience.<ref>Lewis, Jo Ann. "Three Painters with a Natural Bond; a Passion for Place and Culture Unites O'Keeffe, Kahlo and Carr". ''The Washington Post'', February 10, 2002.<http://search.proquest.com/docview/409252883></ref><ref>Bauer, Claudia. ''Frida Kahlo''. New Yorhttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reusing_Wikipedia_contentk: Prestel, 2007. Page 107.</ref> The pain she represents is not only physical, but emotional torment caused by her relationship with husband, [[Diego Rivera]].<ref>Bauer, Claudia. ''Frida Kahlo''. New York: Prestel, 2007. Page 107.</ref> Compared to the grand murals of her [[Mexican muralism|Mexican]] contemporaries, such as Diego Rivera, [[David Alfaro Siqueiros]], and [[José Clemente Orozco]], the paintings of Frida Kahlo were small. Some critics interpret the scale of her works as a sign of isolation, which also downplays her painful circumstances.<ref>Booker, Bobbi. "Private Kahlo Works Unveiled". ''Philadelphia Tribune'', February 17, 2008. <http://search.proquest.com/docview/337870948></ref>
It is Mexican tradition to place a broken branch on a grave. This is taken as an acknowledgement of the artist's deteriorating health.<ref>[[Judy Chicago]] and [[Frances Borzello]]. ''Frida Kahlo: Face to Face''. Munich; New York: [[Prestel Publishing|Prestel]], 2012. Page 238.</ref> Despite the wounds on the body of the deer, Kahlo does not paint a face of anguish, but of strength.<ref>Bauer, Claudia. ''Frida Kahlo''. New York: Prestel, 2007. Page 107.</ref>
Scholars point out that the antlers on Kahlo's head are those of a stag, a male deer.<ref>Delgado, Marina. "The Female Grotesque in the Works of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Isabelle Allende, and Frida Kahlo". The University of Texas at Dallas, ProQuest, UMI Dissertations Publishing, 2010.</ref><ref>Dosamantes-Beaudry, Irma. "Frida Kahlo: Self-Other Representation and Self-Healing Through Art". ''The Arts in Psychotherapy'' 28, no. 1, February 2001. Pages 5-17.</ref><ref>Grimberg, Salomon. ''Frida Kahlo: Song of Herself''. London; New York: Merrell, 2008. Pages 26-27.</ref> Kahlo is representing herself as part male and part female, as well as elements of human and animal features. This hybrid form is often explained by the artist's influence of [[pre-Columbian]] ideas and traditions, which hold the belief that the right foot is represented by a deer.<ref>Delgado, Marina. "The Female Grotesque in the Works of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Isabel Allende, and Frida Kahlo". The University of Texas at Dallas, ProQuest, UMI Dissertations Publishing, 2010.</ref><ref>Grimberg, Salomon. ''Frida Kahlo: Song of Herself''. London; New York: Merrell, 2008. Pages 26-27.</ref> In this belief system, days were represented by a symbol and a number. Important dates such as birthdays were used in predictions. Kahlo adopted the deer as a symbol for herself because of its connection to the right foot, and in the [[Aztec]] calendar, she was born on day nine. These two symbols together were not good, as nine was a symbol for earthly elements as well as the underworld, which was made up of nine phases.<ref>Grimberg, Salomon. ''Frida Kahlo: Song of Herself''. London; New York: Merrell, 2008. Pages 26-27.</ref> The number nine can be seen twice in ''The Wounded Deer'': there are nine trees in the left side, before the clearing that reveals the ocean and lightning bolt, as well as nine arrows protruding from the body of the deer. An additional nine can be seen in the points of her antlers, if counted together.
In the painting, the deer's front right leg is raised off the ground, perhaps in a reflection of Kahlo's own impairment.<ref>Grimberg, Salomon. ''Frida Kahlo: Song of Herself''. London; New York: Merrell, 2008. Pages 26-27.</ref> At the time she painted ''The Wounded Deer'', Kahlo had difficulty walking, which she would attempt to correct through a spinal surgery later that year.<ref>Kahlo, Frida. ''The Diary of Frida Kahlo: an Intimate Self-Portrait''. New York: N.H. Abrams, 1995. Page 265.</ref>
Some art historians believe that Frida Kahlo's decision to portray herself with male and female features is a reflection of her own sexuality.<ref>Delgado, Marina. "The Female Grotesque in the Works of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Isabel Allende, and Frida Kahlo." The University of Texas at Dallas, ProQuest, UMI Dissertations Publishing, 2010.</ref> This perception recognizes her [[bisexuality]]. Other interpretations of the figure relate the male and female elements, referred to as [[hermaphrodite|hermaphroditic]], to pre-Columbian [[Aztec]] beliefs that hold relationships between animals and parts of the human body.<ref>Delgado, Marina. "The Female Grotesque in the Works of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Isabel Allende, and Frida Kahlo". The University of Texas at Dallas, ProQuest, UMI Dissertations Publishing, 2010.</ref>
The meaning of the word "[[karma|carma]]", painted in the lower left corner of the painting, is controversial. It was Kahlo's own belief that her life was planned out by destiny or fate, and therefore she could not prevent any of the difficulties she faced.<ref>Grimberg, Salomon. ''Frida Kahlo: Song of Herself''. London; New York: Merrell, 2008. Pages 26-27.</ref> Consequently, her misfortune must have been caused by deeds from her previous lives.
An influence of [[Christianity]] is also integrated through reference to the story of [[Saint Sebastian]], a martyr who was tied to a tree and shot by arrows.<ref>Lewis, Jo Ann. "Three Painters with a Natural Bond: A Passion for Place and Culture Unites O'Keeffe, Kahlo and Carr". ''The Washington Post'', February 10, 2002.<http://search.proquest.com/docview/409252883></ref><ref>"Saint Sebastian | Biography - Christian Martyr". Encyclopædia Britannica Online. Accessed April 15, 2015. <http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/531221/Saint-Sebastian></ref>
The pre-Columbian, Buddhist, and Christian symbols combine to reflect Kahlo's multi-cultural reality - a reality which also represents a spectrum of gender possibilities. Frida Kahlo renders herself with these juxtaposing features to explore the concept of the self. Through these changes, identity is seen as dynamic and complex, not a fixed state.<ref>Kahlo, Frida. ''Frida Kahlo''. London: Tate Publishing. 2005. Pages 42-43.</ref>

Not including it will default it to cm.--> | imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. Not including it will default it to in.--> | city = [[Paris, France]] | museum = [[Musée National d'Art Moderne]] | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = }} The '''''Yellow Crucifixion''''' is a painting by [[Marc Chagall]]. It was painted in 1943 and is on display at [[Musée National d'Art Moderne]] in [[Paris, France]].
== Description of Artwork ==
The piece reworked many themes that first occurred in Chagall's more famous artwork ''[[White Crucifixion]]'' whereby the suffering of Jewish victims of [[the Holocaust]] was communicated through the image of [[Jesus]] [[Christ (title)|Christ]] as a Jew.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://diglotting.com/2014/02/28/theology-and-art-chagalls-crucifixion-in-yellow/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-08-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150816111522/http://diglotting.com/2014/02/28/theology-and-art-chagalls-crucifixion-in-yellow/ |archivedate=2015-08-16 |df= }}</ref>
Jesus is not the central image of this picture, and instead shares the canvas with a large green Torah scroll and [[angel]]. This positioning emphasises the Jewish character of Jesus in this work, supported by Jesus wearing a Jewish prayer shawl ([[tallit]]) and [[tefillin]].<ref>J. Cohen. Christ Killers. Oxford. 2007. p.166</ref>
The surrounding details are scenes from the programs occurring in Europe. There is a burning [[shtetl]] to the right, surrounded by distressed looking figures. Below this is found a Jew wearing traditional Jewish clothing (and a placard) and a fleeing woman with her child.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://diglotting.com/2014/02/28/theology-and-art-chagalls-crucifixion-in-yellow/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-08-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150816111522/http://diglotting.com/2014/02/28/theology-and-art-chagalls-crucifixion-in-yellow/ |archivedate=2015-08-16 |df= }}</ref> The latter scene is reminiscent of the story of Jesus’ flight to Egypt as a child.<ref>The Bible. Matt. 2.13-15</ref>
Another theme that has been reworked into the ''Yellow Crucifixion'', which first appeared in the ''White Crucifixion'', is the presence of a ship. The significant difference is that in this painting, the ship is shown sinking into the waters. This is undoubtably an allusion to the [[Struma disaster|''Struma'' disaster]] in 1942. The fact that Jesus is looking down on the ship, watching the passengers, is said to convey the artist's own passage to [[New York City]] from Europe that took place by ship.<ref>J. Cohen. Christ Killers. Oxford. 2007. p.166</ref>
Other details include fish leaping out of the sea and a goat.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://diglotting.com/2014/02/28/theology-and-art-chagalls-crucifixion-in-yellow/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-08-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150816111522/http://diglotting.com/2014/02/28/theology-and-art-chagalls-crucifixion-in-yellow/ |archivedate=2015-08-16 |df= }}</ref>
== Influence of Piece ==
Reformed theologian Jürgen Moltmann mentions this painting as being his muse while writing ''The Crucified God'', a book which has been called a Christian [[Holocaust theology|theology after Auschwitz]]:
"In front of me hangs Marc Chagall’s picture ''Crucifixion in Yellow''. It shows the figure of the crucified Christ in an apocalyptic situation: people sinking into the sea, people homeless and in flight, and yellow fire blazing in the background. And with the crucified Christ there appears the angel with the trumpet and the open roll of the book of life [Rev 14.6]. This picture has accompanied me for a long time. It symbolizes the cross on the horizon of the world, and can be thought of as a symbolic expression of the studies which follow." <ref>''The Crucified God'', xxii; See also Moltmann’s autobiography, ''A Broad Place'', p.191</ref>

'''Theatre Pro Rata''' is a small, professional theatre company operating in the [[Minneapolis-Saint Paul|Twin Cities]], United States. The company's name is derived from the term [[pro rata]], which comes from the Latin for "in proportion." Their mission: To each of us: a foundation in the play, a pursuit of creative excellence, and a continuation of curiosity.[http://www.theatreprorata.org Theatre Pro Rata website] Formed in 2000 under the artistic direction of '''Carin Bratlie''', the company gained local notoriety with ''[[Trainspotting (novel)#Stage adaptation|Trainspotting]]'' as part of the 2002 Minnesota Fringe Festival. Shortly thereafter, Theatre Pro Rata began to produce regular seasons and has taken up residence at the [[Gremlin Theatre]] in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]]. In 2008, ''Metamorphoses'' was named one of the top ten productions of the year by ''[[Lavender Magazine]]'' {{cite news| author=John Townsend | title=2008 Theater Year in Review | work=Lavender Magazine |url=http://www.lavendermagazine.com/archives/issue-354/2008-theater-year-in-review/ | year=2008 | accessdate=2009-04-08}} and the set design for ''Killer Joe'' named among the best of 2008 by ''[[City Pages]]''.{{cite news| author=Quinton Skinner | title=The Year's Best Set Designs | work=City Pages |url=http://www.citypages.com/2008-12-24/arts/the-year-s-best-set-designs/ | year=2008 | accessdate=2009-04-08}} In April 2009, Theatre Pro Rata produced [[David Hare (playwright)|David Hare]]'s translation of [[Bertolt Brecht]]'s ''[[The Life of Galileo]]'', coinciding with the [[International Year of Astronomy]] and featuring a gender-blind cast led by Noë Tallen in the title role. Beginning in 2015 with their production of The Illusion by Tony Kushner, Theatre Pro Rata will perform one show of each season at Park Square Theatre's new Andy Boss Thrust Stage as part of a theatrical collaboration between the two companies. == Shows == '''2001:''' ''All Choked Up/White Noise''
'''2002:''' ''Trainspotting'' ([http://www.talkinbroadway.com/regional/minn/minn13.html Talkin' Broadway review]; [http://www.citypages.com/2002-12-04/arts/life-is-shite City Pages review])
'''2004:''' ''Much Ado About Nothing''; ''Emma'' ([http://www.talkinbroadway.com/regional/minn/minn90.html Talkin' Broadway review])
'''2005:''' ''Hamlet'' and ''Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead'' ([http://www.talkinbroadway.com/regional/minn/minn128.html Talkin' Broadway review])
'''2006:''' ''Slag Heap'' ([http://www.talkinbroadway.com/regional/minn/minn150.html Talkin' Broadway review]); ''Machinal'' ([http://www.backstage.com/bso/news_reviews/midwest/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003124479 Backstage review])
'''2007:''' ''Quills'' ([http://www.talkinbroadway.com/regional/minn/minn191.html Talkin' Broadway review]; [http://www.citypages.com/2007-05-09/arts/sadists-have-feelings-too/ City Pages review]); ''365 Plays/365 Days''; ''Feelgood Hits Of The 70s'' ([http://www.citypages.com/2007-05-09/arts/sadists-have-feelings-too/ City Pages review]); ''Dusa, Fish, Stas, and Vi''

'''2009:''' ''The Life of Galileo'' ([http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/onstage/42527407.html?elr=KArksc:iaEQDU_3OyBooUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aULPQL7PQLanchO7DiU Minneapolis Star Tribune review]; [http://www.howwastheshow.com/index.cfm/action/reviews.view/reviewKey/1143 HowWasTheShow.com review]; [http://www.citypages.com/2009-04-08/arts/brecht-s-life-of-galileo-turns-a-telescope-on-humanity City Pages review]); ''Monster'' ([http://www.fringefestival.org/2009/show/?id=1164 Minnesota Fringe Festival Reviews]); ''Marisol'' ([http://www.citypages.com/2009-10-14/arts/theatre-pro-rata-s-marisol-stages-coup-against-a-demented-almighty/ City Pages Review]; [http://www.tcdailyplanet.net/news/2009/10/06/review-marisol-theatre-pro-rata-5-stars TC Daily Planet Review])

'''2012:''' ''T Bone N Weasel'' ([http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/stageandarts/141488473.html Star Tribune Review]; [http://www.citypages.com/2012-03-07/arts/spotlight-t-bone-n-weasel/ City Pages Review]); ''44 Plays for 44 Presidents'' ([http://www.twincities.com/stage/ci_20985323/theatre-pro-ratas-44-plays-44-presidents-review Pioneer Press Review]); ''Lovers & Executioners''

[[File:Joaquín Murieta, The California Bandit.jpg|thumb|Picture, possibly by [[Charles Nahl]], of "[[Joaquin Murieta|Joaquín Murieta]], The California Bandit", from the rarest book of the Zamorano 80, ''The Life and Adventures of Joaquín Murieta'', 1854]] The '''Zamorano Eighty''' is a list of books intended to represent the most significant early volumes published on the [[History of California|history]] of [[California]]. It was compiled in 1945 by members of the Zamorano Club, a [[Los Angeles]]-based group of [[bibliophile]]s. Collecting [[first edition]]s of every volume on the list has become the goal of a number of book collectors, though to date only four people have completed the task.<ref name="volkmann">{{cite news | url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Dan-Volkmann-collector-of-rare-books-dies-3162597.php | title=Dan Volkmann, collector of rare books, dies | publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]] | work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date=May 7, 2009 | accessdate=May 30, 2013 | author=Tucker, Jill}}</ref>
The Zamorano Club was founded in 1928 and named for [[Agustín Vicente Zamorano]], the first [[Printer (publisher)|printer]] in California.<ref name="zhistory">{{cite web | url=http://www.zamoranoclubla.org/history/ | title=History of the Zamorano Club | publisher=The Zamorano Club | accessdate=June 3, 2013 | author=Nunis, Doyce B., Jr.}}</ref><ref name="Madness">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Z-KL2voBoUC | title=A Gentle Madness: Bibliophiles, Bibliomanes, and the Eternal Passion for Books | publisher=Henry Holt and Company | author=Basbanes, Nicholas A. | authorlink=Nicholas A. Basbanes | date=March 15, 1999 | pages=492–6 | isbn=978-0-8050-6176-5}}</ref><ref name="Clifford ">{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-09-18/local/me-3445_1_zamorano-club | title=An Exclusive Club of Many Chapters | publisher=[[Tribune Company]] | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=September 18, 1988 | accessdate=June 4, 2013 | author=Soble, Ronald L.}}</ref> A series of committees of Club members, including former [[American Smelting and Refining Company]] executive [[Henry Raup Wagner]] and bibliographer Robert Cowan, assembled a list of a hundred books, eventually whittled down to eighty. During this process, Cowan died, and his ''Bibliography of the History of California and the Pacific West'' was added to the list as a tribute.<ref name="z80">{{cite web | url=http://www.zamoranoclubla.org/zam80/ | title=The Zamorano 80 | publisher=The Zamorano Club | accessdate=June 4, 2013}}</ref>
The list contains significant works by a number of well-known authors like [[Mark Twain]], [[John Muir]], [[Bret Harte]], and [[Robert Louis Stevenson]], as well as obscure texts concerning geographical exploration and legal matters. Some of the works exist in very few, highly sought after copies, while others were quite common and not particularly valuable, until interest in the list caused their prices to rise.<ref name="Water2010">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pIuC3A4_v_UC | title=The Zamorano 80 Revisited: A Collector's Update of a Classic Work | publisher=Xlibris Corporation | date=April 16, 2010 | accessdate=May 30, 2013 | author=Gordon J. Water | page=xi | isbn=978-1-4628-1868-6}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=January 2018}}</ref> Book dealers often refer to items for sale using their "Zamorano number" or have special sections dedicated to items on the list.
Thomas Streeter was the first collector to assemble a complete collection of first editions of every item on the list. His collection was auctioned between 1966 and 1969.<ref name="z80"/> Businessman Frederick William Beinecke was the second. Retired investment counselor Henry H. Clifford completed his collection in 1988 and his collection was auctioned in 1995. The fourth was architect Daniel Volkmann, who completed his collection in 1994, and it was auctioned in 2003.<ref name=volkmann /><ref name="z80"/><ref name=Clifford /> Many other collectors have pursued this goal, including notorious [[bibliomane]] and book thief [[Stephen Blumberg]].<ref name=Madness />
Only one institution, the [[Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library]] at [[Yale University]], possesses a complete collection of the Zamorano 80, donated by Frederick W. Beinecke. Both the [[Bancroft Library]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] and the [[Huntington Library]] in [[San Marino, California]] possess all but one of the volumes.<ref name="Sloan">{{cite web | url=http://www.dsloan.com/Auctions/A12/DSIntro.htm | title=The Zamorano 80 | publisher=Dorothy Sloan Books | accessdate=May 30, 2013 | author=Sloan, Dorothy}}</ref>
The rarest book on the list is number 64, the [[dime novel]] ''[[The Life and Adventures of Joaquín Murieta]]'' by [[John Rollin Ridge]] writing as "Yellow Bird". Only two first-edition copies are known to exist, each used twice to complete the list.<ref name=sloanJM /> It may be on the list only because Wagner owned a copy, which he sold to Streeter. When Streeter's collection was being periodically auctioned, the auction of this copy was moved up over a year so the elderly Beinecke would be able to complete his Zamorano collection. This copy is now in the Beinecke Library with the rest of Beinecke's Zamorano books.<ref name="sloanJM">{{cite web | url=http://www.dsloan.com/Auctions/A12/64WebA12.htm | title=Auction 12: The Zamorano 80 Collection of Daniel G. Volkmann Jr. Lots 64 & 64A Item 64. The exceedingly rare Life and Adventures of Joaquín Murieta | publisher=Dorothy Sloan Books | accessdate=June 4, 2013}}</ref><ref name="AE">{{cite journal | url=http://www.americanaexchange.com/articles/27 | title=The Elusive Zamorano 80 Captured Again: The Volkmann Zamorano 80 under the Hammer in February | author=Wilkie, Everett | journal=Americana Exchange Monthly | accessdate=June 4, 2013}}</ref> Clifford purchased the second copy from a collector in Maine, which in turn was purchased by Volkmann at the auction of Clifford's collection.<ref name=Water2010 /><ref name=Clifford /> The book has been described with terms like "[[Holy Grail]]"<ref name=volkmann /> and "[[wikt:Special:Search/rara avis|rara avis]]"<ref name="sloanJM"/> and is highly desired by collectors. Blumberg wanted it so much he and his accomplices planned and researched a potential burglary of Clifford's house when that collector owned the book.<ref name=Madness />
==The Zamorano Eighty==
The works on the list are numbered in alphabetical order by author (or title, in the case of numbers 14, 35, and 62) and were not intended to be any sort of ranking of literary or financial value.
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! # !! Author !! Title !!
